Leo Dagum wrote:
> Thanks for the explanation!  I retried the crawl monitoring more closely,
> but was unable to reproduce the situation where 90% of my queues became
> exhausted in short order.  I'm now getting the behavior I expected.
> 
> A related question: can you explain the different cost-policies?  I
> understand zero-cost and unit-cost, but wag-cost and anti-calendar-cost are
> a mystery to me.

A higher 'cost' URI has three main effects: (1) its queue spends less 
time in active rotation; (2) its queue may reach the total-budget cap 
sooner; (3) it sorts further back into the queue when inserted.

WagCostAssignmentPolicy is based on some wild guesses of kinds of URIs
that should be treated as higher cost. It starts like unit-cost, with 
all URIs costing 1, but then adds 1 if the URI has a query-string, and 
then adds 1 more if the non-query-string portion is identical to the 
URI's 'via'. So, it biases crawling against URIs with query-strings, and 
especially those chains of references where only the query-string changes.

Is that reasonable? We don't know; we haven't tested. This policy has 
fallen out of favor in our own crawling because if there is junk content 
without a query-string, and quality content with a query-string, this 
defers the quality query-string content behind the junk, which may be 
massive.

AntiCalendarCostAssignmentPolicy also starts like unit-cost, but adds 1 
if the URI looks like it might be calendar URI, according to a built-in 
regex. The regex is imperfect, and there is a risk quality calendar 
content will be stuck behind junk non-calendar content, but the hope was 
to bias crawls against endless or negligible-value calendar pages.
